definition:
Let $R$ be a subring of a commutative ring $S$. If $f$ is a polynomial
in $R[X]$, it defines an evaluation homomorphism from $S$ to $S$. Any
element $\alpha$ of $S$ satisfying $$f(\alpha) \;=\; 0$$ is a [*zero of
the polynomial*]{} $f$.

If $R$ also is equipped with a non-zero unity, then the polynomial $f$
is in $S[X]$ divisible by the binomial $X\!-\!\alpha$ (cf. the factor
theorem). In this case, if $f$ is divisible by $(X\!-\!\alpha)^n$ but
not by $(X\!-\!\alpha)^{n+1}$, then $\alpha$ is a zero of the *order*
$n$ of the polynomial $f$. If this order is 1, then $\alpha$ is a
*simple zero* of $f$.

For example, the real number $\sqrt{2}$ ($\in \mathbb{R}$) is a zero of
the polynomial $X^2\!-\!2$ of the polynomial ring $\mathbb{Q}[X]$.
